page.title: 12ST MARY'S CHURCH (C.E.)
page.content: {St. Mary's Church}was mentioned in the original{Domesday Book}of 1086; the base of its square tower is still the original{Norman}stonework. The church and its precincts abound in history. For example, in the grounds near to the Lych Gate, is a Saxon Preaching Cross which is thought to have once stood at "The Cross", Kingswinford, in the present settlement. Several of the old gravestones are thought to have been used by Oliver Cromwell's men in the{seventeenth {century}to sharpen their swords and pikes. (Deep grooves are on them). At one time St. Mary's Church was in the centre of the village but nowadays it lies very much on its outskirts. Nevertheless it has an active congregation and very regular worship with a vicar and a curate to serve the parish's pastoral needs.
